content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

The position of a particle moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x of 0 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x prime of t equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, t raised to the 1.1 power, close parenthesis, times, the square root of, 10 t plus 4, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1.1</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the open interval <math alttext="0 less than t, less than 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> when the particle changes direction. Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

The position of a particle moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x of 0 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x prime of t equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, t raised to the 1.1 power, close parenthesis, times, the square root of, 10 t plus 4, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1.1</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the open interval <math alttext="0 less than t, less than 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> when the particle changes direction. Give a reason for your answer.

(b) Find the total distance traveled by the particle from time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.

(c) Find the acceleration of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the speed of the particle increasing or decreasing at time <math alttext="t equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> ?  Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Find the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is there a time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> when the particle is at the origin? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
